questions.question: During a routine colonoscopy of a 60-year-old male, a small polyp is identified in the colon. Subsequent biopsy results confirm the presence of a hyperplastic polyp. Which characteristic is typically associated with this condition?

options.A: Commonly found in the right colon
options.B: Pathogenesis involves increased epithelial cell turnover
options.D: Histologically composed of immature goblet cells

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lacks malignant potential Explanation : The characteristic of hyperplastic polyps is that they lack malignant potential. Hyperplastic polyps: Lacks malignant potential Benign epithelial proliferations occurring commonly in the 6th-7th decade. Formed due to decreased epithelial cell turnover and delayed shedding, resulting in a piling up of goblet and absorptive cells. (Option B) Usually less than 5 mm with a smooth, nodular appearance and commonly found in the left colon. (Option A) Mature goblet cells and absorptive cells with serrated surface architecture are hallmark findings. (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 807

questions.question: A 55-year-old man undergoes a routine colonoscopy. During the procedure, a polyp is discovered. Histological examination reveals serrated architecture, as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this polyp?

options.B: Predominantly found in the left colon
options.C: Serrated architecture is limited to the surface of the lesions
options.D: Do not require surveillance or follow-up after detection

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It has malignant potential Explanation: The above image shows serrations throughout the full length of the glands including crypt base which is suggestive of sessile serrated adenoma which has malignant potential. Sessile Serrated Adenomas (SSA): Exhibit serrated architecture throughout the full length of the gland while hyperplastic polyps have serrated architecture only in the upper third of the crypt. (Option C) It has malignant potential More commonly located in the right colon. (Option B) Lack typical cytologic features of dysplasia found in other adenomas. Early precursor lesions in the serrated neoplasia pathway. Associated with BRAF-mutated colorectal carcinomas. Require follow-up surveillance for monitoring changes or growth. (Option D) Hyperplastic polyp Sessile serrated polyp Pathology Piling up of goblet and absorptive cells due to decreased epithelial cell turnover and delayed shedding Due to proliferation of epithelial cells Predominant site Left colon

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl presents to the OPD with complaints of rectal bleeding and abdominal pain for the past six months. Investigations reveal approximately 40 hamartomatous colon polyps. The biopsy shows cystic spaces with dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Juvenile polyposis syndrome Explanation: The given clinical presentation and investigation findings suggests a possible diagnosis of Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome (JPS). Juvenile polyposis Syndrome Primarily affects children under 5 years old. Autosomal dominant inheritance Can be sporadic or syndromic. Sporadic: Single polyps. Syndromic: 3-100 polyps. Linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF- β signaling pathway. Pedunculated polyp which is usually less than 3 cm in diameter. Contains cystic spaces filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. Extra-intestinal manifestations include congenital malformations, digital clubbing. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 808-809

questions.question: A 13-year-old female presents to the OPD due to abdominal pain and blood in stools. On examination, she had pigmented macules on her lips and oral mucosa. Endoscopy reveals multiple large, pedunculated polyps in the small intestine which shows an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition? Autosomal dominant disorder Polyps are more common in the colon Increased risk of developing colon, pancreatic, and breast cancers Gain-of-function mutation in STK11 gene

A 58-year-old female presents with weight loss, nail changes, alopecia, and skin hyperpigmentation. Colonoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the intestine. Family history is negative for intestinal cancers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome Explanation: The clinical presentation and multiple noncancerous polyps in the colon, coupled with a lack of family history of similar symptoms suggests Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome (CCS). Cronkhite-Canada syndrome Rare, non-hereditary condition Mean age of presentation: >50 years Characterized by: Widespread non cancerous/hamartomatous gastrointestinal polyposis Cutaneous changes - alopecia, hyperpigmentation) Nail dystrophy Polyps: Symptoms: Malabsorption, diarrhea, weight loss Tuberous sclerosis (Option A) is a neurocutaneous disorder resulting from mutations in the TSC1 (hamartin) or TSC2 (tuberin) genes. Patients exhibit neurological symptoms like seizures, along with skin abnormalities. The syndrome also includes hamartomatous polyps in the intestine. Bannayan-Ruvalcaba-Riley Syndrome (Option B) is a genetic condition characterized by macrocephaly, intestinal hamartomatous polyps and pigmented maculae of the glans penis. Cowden syndrome (Option C) is caused by mutation of PTEN gene on chromosome 10. It is associated with multiple hamartomatous polyps, benign skin tumors like trichilemmoma and an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 809

questions.question: A 20-year-old man with a family history of colorectal carcinoma presents with chronic abdominal discomfort and occasional rectal bleeding.Upon further evaluation, a mutation in APC gene is identified leading to a diagnosis of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis. Which of the following statement is true regarding FAP?

options.B: 50 % risk of colon cancer if untreated
options.C: Presence of a minimum of 100 polyps
options.D: Congenital atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presence of a minimum of 100 polyps. Explanation: Classic FAP is characterized by the presence of a minimum of 100 polyps Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) Autosomal dominant disorder caused by APC gene mutations on chromosome 5 (Option A) Numerous intestinal polyps develop Classic FAP: Diagnosed with at least 100 polyps (Option C) Almost 100% risk of colorectal cancer if untreated (Option B) Commonly develops by 30 years, almost always by 50 years Attenuated FAP (AFAP): Primarily affects the proximal colon Fewer polyps (average <30 polyps) Associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (Option D) Standard treatment: Prophylactic colectomy to prevent colorectal cancer Post-colectomy risks: Cancer at extracolonic sites, including the ampulla of Vater and stomach FAP gross" data-author="Department of Pathology, Calicut Medical College" data-hash="755" data-license="CC BY SA 4.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Familial_Adenomatous_Polyposes_colon_-2.jpg" data-tags="January2025" height="400" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Ubf3jpEH6EikeIUZtkTP1737000901.png" width="500" /> Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 812 https://www.uptodate.com/cont ents/clinical-manifestations-and-diagnosis-of-familial-adenomatous-polyposis?search=FAP&source=search_result &selectedTitle=1%7E150&usage_type=default&display_rank=1#H534324165

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of unexplained weight loss along with multiple sebaceous cysts on her face and scalp. She has a family history of colorectal cancer. Upon further examination, she is found to have a bony lesion on her jaw. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:B) Gardner syndrome Explanation The clinical findings given suggest Gardner syndrome as a possible diagnosis. Gardner syndrome An autosomal dominant condition Characterized by colonic polyposis and extracolonic manifestations Due to mutations in APC gene Predisposition to colo-rectal cancer present Extracolonic manifestations include Osteomas (commonly in skull and mandible) Supernumerary teeth Epidermoid cysts Fibromas Thyroid and desmoid tumors Supernumerary teeth Option A) Turcot syndrome: Turcot syndrome can also arise from mutations in APC genes. But, there is association with brain tumors along with colorectal cancer Option C) Lynch syndrome: AKA HNPCC(hereditary non polyposis colorectal cancer) Autosomal dominant condition due to mutations in MLH 1 and MSH 2 Characterized by increases risk of colorectal cancer, endometrial, ovarian, uterus and Pancreatic cancers Option D) MUTYH Associated Polyposis (MAP) Rare autosomal recessive disorder due to mutations in the MUTYH gene. Occurs later in life compared to other polyposis syndromes Involves fewer than 100 polyps and individuals with MAP have an increased risk of colorectal cancer. Unlike Gardner syndromes, MAP is not associated with osteomas or epidermoid cysts. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 809, 813 Gardner syndrome - UpToDate

questions.question: A 6 cm polyp is identified in the descending colon during a routine colonoscopy. Histological examination reveals villous architecture with high-grade dysplasia. Based on this scenario, which factors most strongly correlate with the risk of malignancy in colorectal adenomas?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Size of the adenoma Explanation: The size of colorectal adenomas is the most critical factor associated with the risk of malignancy. Larger adenomas are most likely to develop into invasive carcinoma Adenomas larger than 4 cm in diameter have nearly a 40% chance of containing invasive cancer. Villous architecture (Option A) : Villous adenomas are associated with a higher incidence of cancer than tubular adenomas, but this correlation primarily arises from their larger size rather than their architectural characteristics alone. Histologic grade of dysplasia (Option C) : High-grade dysplasia within an individual polyp increases its risk of harboring cancer. However, histologic grade of dysplasia is not the primary factor correlating with the overall risk of malignancy across adenomas. Gastrointestinal tract location (Option D) : While certain types of polyps may have preferences for specific locations within the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., sessile serrated lesions are more common in the right colon), location alone is not the strongest predictor of malignancy in colorectal adenomas. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 810, 811

questions.question: A patient underwent genetic testing after being diagnosed with colon cancer. Testing reveals a mutation associated with Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). Which of the following genes is defective in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) MLH1 and MSH2 Explanation: Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome, is caused by inherited mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes - MSH2 and MLH1. Genes mutation Manifestation MLH1, MSH2 (Option D) Results in microsatellite instability Causes cluster of cancer: Colorectal, Endometrial, Ovarian, Pancreatic cancers Colon cancer develops at a young age and it usually occurs in the right side SMAD4 and BMPR1 (Option A) Juvenile polyposis syndrome STK11 (Option B) Peutz-Jeghers syndrome APC gene (Option C) Familial Adenomatous Polyposis(FAP), sporadic colon cancer, Gardner syndrome and Turcot syndrome MUTYH (Option C) MUTYH-associated polyposis. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 809, 813

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent abdominal discomfort and changes in bowel habits over the past few months. Further investigation with colonoscopy confirmed the presence of adenocarcinoma. Which of the following factors is most closely associated with this condition?

options.C: High intake of unabsorbable vegetable fiber

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) High consumption of red meat Explanation: High consumption of red meat is associated with increased risk of adenocarcinoma of the colon Factors increasing the risk Factors decreasing the risk Low fiber, high fat diet High intake of red meat and processed meat Increased calorie intake and obesity F amily history of colon cancer Personal history of adenomas Smoking and alcohol Inflammatory bowel disease Lynch syndrome FAP Acromegaly Pelvis irradiation Streptococcus bovis septicemia Ureterosigmoidoscopy High fiber diet Intake of fish (omega-3 fatty acids), fruits and vegetables (Vit A, C, E) NSAID use, particularly Aspirin Folic acid Calcium Hormone replacement therapy Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 814 https://www.uptodate.com/cont ents/epidemiology-and-risk-factors-for-colorectal-cancer?search=adenocarcinoma%20colon&topicRef=2496&sou rce=see_link#H2

questions.question: A 55-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, unintended weight loss. A previous colonoscopy showed a polyp, but a recent one confirmed colorectal adenocarcinoma. Which gene mutations are characteristically associated with development of colorectal adenocarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) APC, KRAS, SMAD4 and TP53 Explanation: The genes associated with development of colorectal carcinoma are APC, KRAS, SMAD4 and TP53. Adenoma-Carcinoma Sequence: Accounts for up to 80% of sporadic cancers. APC Gene Mutations: Leads to β -catenin accumulation and Wnt pathway activation. "First hit": Sporadic inactivation of APC. "Second hit": Loss of second APC copy KRAS Mutations: Promote growth and prevent apoptosis. SMAD2 and SMAD4 Mutations: Disrupt TGF- β pathway, causing uncontrolled proliferation. TP53 Mutations: Occur in later stages of tumor progression. carcinoma sequence" data-author="NA" data-hash="758" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="January2025" height="765" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/jK2AYUAKNQCxiKjCy6wb1737002038.png" width="1000" /> Other gene mutations associated with adenocarcinoma colon Genes Function/ association BRAF Less common; involved in MAPK pathway TGFBR2 Less common; part of the TGF- β signalling pathway MYC Less common; involved in cell proliferation MLH1 DNA mismatch repair deficiency leads to MSI BAX Less common pro-apoptotic protein Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 815

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, and weight loss. Her mother and aunt were diagnosed with endometrial and ovarian cancer in their 50s. A colonoscopy and a biopsy confirm well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Which genetic pathway is most likely associated with adenocarcinoma in this patient? β -catenin pathway β signaling pathway
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) DNA mismatch repair pathway Explanation: The patient's family history of endometrial and ovarian cancer, combined with her well-differentiated adenocarcinoma, suggests Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) which is associated with DNA mismatch repair pathway Lynch syndrome occurs due to germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes resulting in microsatellite instability (MSI) Option A) APC/ β -catenin pathway: This is commonly associated with the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence in colorectal adenocarcinoma. Options B & D): TGF- β signaling pathway and pro-apoptotic protein BAX regulate cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. While these signalling pathways are alterations in colorectal cancer, they are not commonly associated with MSI or Lynch syndrome. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 815

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis for colon adenocarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : D) Liver Explanation: The liver is the most common site of distant metastasis for colon adenocarcinoma. This is due to the portal venous drainage of the colon, which allows cancer cells to spread easily to the liver. Other sites :Lymph nodes, lungs, and bones can metastasize Prognostic factors Depth of invasion Lymph node metastases. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 816 Lung-Seeking Metastases - PMC Bone Metastases: An Overview - PMC Brain metastases: an overview - PMC

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, altered bowel habits and 5kg weight loss in one month. A barium enema study showed the following finding. Which of the following statements is true about the patient's condition?

options.A: Presents asweakness due to iron deficiency anemia
options.B: Leads to a napkin-ring constriction and luminal narrowing
options.C: Growth tends to be polypoidal (growth is into the wall of the intestine?)

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Leads to a napkin-ring constriction and luminal narrowing Explanation: Distal colorectal carcinoma leads to formation of a napkin ring constriction and luminal narrowing which can be seen as an apple core appearance on barium enema study Proximal adenocarcinoma (masses on the caecum and ascending colon) Grow as polypoidal and exophytic masses which extend along one wall. (Option C) Present with occult anemia, causing late-stage weakness. (Option A) Distal Adenocarcinoma Equally distributed along the colon. Lesions are annular, causing napkin-ring constrictions and luminal narrowing.(Option B) Barium study - apple core appearance Present early with changes in bowel habits, Hematochezia, cramping, left lower quadrant pain. Cell Composition: Tall columnar cells resembling dysplastic epithelium in adenomas. Mucinous Adenocarcinoma:Contains signet-ring cells producing abundant mucin. They are rare and associated with poor prognosis. (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 816 Colon Cancer - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)
